defaultProfiles.description: I am a Professor of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Hawaii, Director of the Collaborative Software Development Laboratory, and the CEO of OpenPowerQuality.com.
I am a Professor of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Hawaii, Director of the Collaborative Software Development Laboratory, and the CEO of OpenPowerQuality.com.

defaultContacts.description: I'm a 3rd year Computer Science student at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. I'm interested in software engineering and web development. I've taken all of the lower division CS courses, and I'm currently taking ICS 314. I love to learn new things and I'm always looking for ways to improve my skills, and help others as well. I'm a very friendly and outgoing person, and I'm always willing to help others. I'm also a very hard worker and I'm always willing to put in the time and effort to get things done. I'm very passionate about what I do, and I'm always looking for ways to improve and grow as a person and as a developer.
I am originally from France. I maintain a list of reports from my surf sessions. I have proof that I ran the Hana relay with an actual Team.

Kim Binsted received her BSc in Physics at McGill (1991), and her PhD in Artificial Intelligence from the University of Edinburgh (1996). Her thesis topic was the computational modeling and generation of punning riddles, and her program, JAPE (Joke Analysis and Production Engine), generated puns such as 'What do you call a Martian who drinks beer? An ale-ien!'.
Carleton Moore is a Researcher in the Department of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. He is a member of the Collaborative Software Development Laboratory.
